summary: This is an email chain between FBI personnel discussing the status of digital evidence processing in the Epstein case. It addresses inventory discrepancies, clarifies the nature of collected items (duplicate hard drives, non-processable voice recorders, software CDs), and notes the US Attorney's Office's concern about the evidence count.

persons.name: SSA - Forensic Examiner CART/OS-I9
persons.context: The sender of the email, working on digital evidence for the Epstein case, offering continued assistance and noting work on outstanding items.

persons.name: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.role: FBI Senior Forensic Examiner / CART Coordinator
persons.context: The author of the forwarded email, providing a detailed status update on digital evidence, explaining discrepancies (duplicate drives, non-evidentiary items), and addressing concerns from the US Attorney's Office.

connections.person2: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Both are FBI forensic examiners corresponding about the status of digital evidence processing in the Epstein case.

events.title: Digital Evidence Status Update
events.description: A senior forensic examiner sends an email with an attached Excel spreadsheet detailing the status of all digital evidence for the Epstein case, addressing inventory discrepancies.
personsInvolved: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: Follow-up on Evidence Status
events.description: An FBI forensic examiner replies to the status update, acknowledging receipt and stating they will continue to work on outstanding items.

keyFacts: There was a discrepancy in the digital evidence inventory that concerned the US Attorney's Office.
Nine hard drives were collected from a New York apartment, but they were 3 duplicates of 3 drives, meaning only 3 unique drives required processing.
Several voice recorders were collected but cannot be processed by CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team).
Ten CDs were collected but were software installation disks containing no user data.
The status update was specifically for items the examiner had 'touched' and was not an exhaustive inventory of the entire case.
